schedule.title: Every Breath You Take: A CTI Review of Stalkerware
schedule.description: A common misconception is that Cyber Threat Intelligence is just for Corporate America or governments. Let’s challenge that assumption with a practical application of CTI to the issue of stalkerware. Security professionals might consider stalkerware a tool for overly-controlling partners or parents, but what if I told you there’s more? Stalkerware presents a hostile actor with a (questionably) legal, commoditized, and easily consumable “software” that has many of the same features of backdoors and other malware we all fight to keep out of our environments, and what wrongdoer wouldn’t take advantage of that? In fact, stalkerware has already been linked to nation-state governments spying on dissidents and journalists. In this talk, you’ll get additional insights into stalkerware; what it is, how it works, who it targets, CTI hypotheses and suggested RFIs to other teams, and of course, no CTI review would be complete without a discussion of the various hostile actors that leverage stalkerware and their tradecraft. Takeaways include glimpses into the dark side of humanity and a report for your threat intelligence platform, as well as ideas of how security professionals can start to tackle this problem as a part of their CTI program.

schedule.title: It’s the end of Critical Infrastructure and I don’t feel fine!
schedule.description: Many times Critical Infrastructure is brought up in news articles and other events without providing a clear understanding on how this is managed within the US.  Additionally the US Government, DHS, DOE, and many others have presented on the Cybersecurity weaknesses within critical infrastructure based on individual sectors, but have never presented on the collected Cybersecurity weaknesses or how the failures in one sector would impact the next.  This presentation will provide a simple overview of how the government manages US Critical infrastructure and some issues that presents.  It will discuss how a simple natural gas or water outage could trickle down through the rest of critical infrastructure over the course of several weeks. The presentation also covers how responding to a ICS related cybersecurity is different to a typical IT cybersecurity incident, and what attendees could do to ensure they are ready and the companies they defend are prepared.  This presentation is beneficial to all cyber teams, physical security, management and other members of a company.

schedule.title: [In]secure deserialization, and how [not] to do it
schedule.description:
Serialized data is neither new nor exciting. Serialization and deserialization have been in use by countless applications, services and frameworks for a long time. Many programming languages support serialization natively, and most people seem to understand it well. However, many of us don’t fully understand security implications of data deserialization, and in the last couple of years this topic got an increasing focus in the security community, up to the point that insecure deserialization made it to the list of OWASP Top 10 most critical web application security risks! Needless to say high-severity vulnerabilities in some well-known applications as well as popular frameworks such as Apache Struts and Apache Commons Collections raised awareness of this risk.

In this session, we’ll discuss how serialized data are used in software, talk about different serialization formats and the dangers of deserializing untrusted input. We will review some real life vulnerabilities and related exploits. The presentation will contain several code examples with live demos of bypassing security controls by exploiting deserialization vulnerabilities. We’ll forge a session cookie, elevate privileges, cause a denial of service, and even perform a remote code execution - all via insecure deserialization! The demos will use native Java, Python and .NET serialization, as well as JSON and XML formats. Of course, we’ll also talk about how to deserialize in secure way!

Next time you develop your awesome web or mobile app or a microservice, keep in mind how a clever attacker could create and supply malicious data to your application, and thinking like a hacker you could write more secure code!

schedule.title: Cyber Harassment: Things I wish I knew when sh1t went sideways
schedule.description:
Cyber harassment is a grey area in both legal and forensic capability. Protecting one’s self can feel impossible, however it is not! 
 
Are words on the internet/emails/private messages considered harassment, seen as threatening, or just freedom of speech?
 
I will share the first-hand extensive knowledge on options. Life tossed me a curveball, which resulted in a life experience which lets me share how to help individuals through a series of options to be protected and for additional help. 
 
Do not feel helpless, evidence can be gathered. Protective orders can be obtained. Individuals who have been harassed causing mental trauma have the right to file for FMLA (NOT just for babies folks!).  This allows them to take the necessary time off work without having a fear of losing employment.
 
The options provided will include tips on how to document and obtain evidence, tips for interviewing lawyers to find an attorney that meets specialized standards for cyber, and how to reach out to get help that can protect an individual in their career.
 
I truly wish I knew during my experiences these options and by sharing my experiences, as long as one person is helped, then it makes my adventure worth it.

schedule.title: Hacking While Blind!
schedule.description: This talk is about how I deal with  the disability of sight loss  to do something I love and was passionate about. Having to push myself to be the best I can and feel successful at something. I will talk about an approach for people who might be blind / VI and, for others to be more inclusive with the people who have a physical disability, and how to team or work with someone with these kinds of issues.

schedule.title: Dumpster Fires: 6 things about IR I learned by being a firefighter
schedule.description: Threats surround us like a ring of burning fire. Unfortunately, incident response doesn't come naturally to an operational mindset where the focus tends to be on reactive problem solving. As a volunteer firefighter for over twenty years, the presenter has learned a lot about what is and isn't effective. There are surprising parallels between fighting real-life fires and the fire-fighting that passes for today’s incident response. For example, striking a balance between swift response and patient reflection is often the the difference between life and death, in a very literal sense for the firefighter and a figurative sense for the security professional. It’s also all too easy to get tunnel vision and focus on the wrong areas, costing precious time. The security world is full of dumpster fires these days, so join this session to learn from a good firefighter what makes a good security person.

schedule.title: The psychology of security awareness
schedule.description: Establishing security culture and awareness isn’t just sending fake phishing emails; it is developing a comprehensive way of thinking that should invoke a sense of curiosity and skepticism. The prevailing methods used today attempt to motivate people based on business security but here’s a secret… Employees don’t care about your business security. This discussion will outline how we got to the current state of security awareness training and how the majority of security programs fall short of true security awareness. It will also cover methodologies that should be incorporated to truly establish critical security thinking not only at work, but in all walks of life.

schedule.title: So You Are Comparing RASP and WAF?
schedule.description: One thing that you learn in the technology space is that change is constant. Companies, solutions, and people who sit on their laurels can find themselves in a position of never-ending catch up. For security operations and application security professionals who rely exclusively on web application firewalls (WAFs) or runtime application security protection (RASP), this talk should open your eyes to better understanding gaps. Tethered to traditional signature-based security approaches, WAFs simply aren't able to keep pace with the changes in the advanced threat landscape. But at the same time, RASP does not provide some of the same bot and DDoS protections that a WAF may provide. And yet, application security professionals are still directly comparing a WAF and RASP as to use one or the other, which is like comparing virus protection and endpoint detection and response (EDR). In this talk we explain the similarities and differences between a WAF and RASP. We will discuss things such as vulnerability deferment, bot detections, antiquated application protections, IP blocking, alert fatigue, etc. We will also dig in to how WAF and RASP should work harmoniously and why you should be utilizing the strengths and benefits of each in your overall application security protection scheme.

schedule.title: What Surviving An Apocalypse Teaches Us About Infosec?
schedule.description: Nothing is more instructive to surviving an apocalypse than living through one. What your survival looks like is all about preparation. In this talk Matt and Tony will share some of their apocalypse survival stories and what can be learned from them. Whether it is the June 29, 2012 North American Derecho, multiple ransomware attacks or traveling to 3rd world nations,   apply to securing your IT shop and your personal data.

schedule.title: Panic! At the Buttons: Hacking Panic Button Systems
schedule.description:
Panic buttons have been part of many physical security architectures for a number of years. Banks, hospitals, and other entities at high risk of physical attacks have used them to inconspicuously alert security or law enforcement to an ongoing event that needs responding to. With the expansion of the Internet of Things, panic buttons, too, have moved into the realm of IoT. Bluetooth and other RF based panic buttons, as well as pure software panic buttons, are now deployed in the world in an attempt to protect property and safety.
 
What problems do these panic buttons inherit from the world of IoT? What security mistakes are IoT panic button manufacturers making? Join us as we answer these questions for a series of real-world panic buttons, including attacks that allow attackers to create fake panic alerts, stop panic alerts in progress, and even entirely prevent alerts from ever being raised.

schedule.title: I Want My EIP: Buffer Overflow 101
schedule.description: When I started learning buffer overflows, I thought it was something everybody else already knew. But the reality is, there are lots of us, just like me, who want to know more but are either overwhelmed by the idea that buffer overflows are beyond their capabilities or just don’t know where to get started. This is a 101-level talk; we’ll talk about how a buffer overflow works, how to fuzz an app to identify an overflow opportunity, and how to create a simple overflow that will result in a compromise of a target system. If you can already smash the stack, spray the heap, and write ROP chains in your sleep, this isn’t the talk for you. If you want to learn more about how simple buffer overflows work and how to write them, this talk is for you. When you leave, you will have the information and resources to help you write your first overflow when you walk out the door.

schedule.title: Compare DevOps to Harry Potter, so that Anyone Can Understand
schedule.description:
This presentation will compare DevOps to the Harry Potter World, making it easier for people to understand the DevOps process.  
Pipeline SW is used to move Code through each DevOps step, comparing it to the Hogwarts Express that moves students to and from school each year. 
For the Dev side of the presentation, Code is collected in a Version Control tool, and code is built as needed, while Hogwarts students must go to Diagon Alley to collect all their supplies. 
Create Unit Tests as part of the build process, and Hogwarts Students get tested by the sorting hat after arriving at Hogwarts. 
Use a SCA or Quality Analysis tool as part of the build process and give examples of student mistakes. 
After code is built it is packaged for release, but when something at Hogwarts needs to be “delivered” it is sent by Owl. 
For the OPS side of the presentation, the teacher will focus on the tools for setting up environments (pre and post environments) for deploying the build.  During this time, we will discuss Ron, Hermione, and Harry’s time growing up and saving the Magic World (there are correlations believe me).

schedule.title: Flex Seal your CI/CD Pipeline
schedule.description:
Continuous Delivery is the heart of DevOps. Web applications, APIs and Microservices are now designed to have the latest version deployed as quickly as possible. This revolution has empowered organizations to develop highly available products and platforms. However, most of the traditional security checks are often bypassed since code can be sent from a repository to a production environment in seconds. 

This talk lays down some strategies on how to continue having an operationally efficient DevOps pipeline while incorporating security throughout the entire process.  Security is a growing concern in this field, not only because the pipeline is a critical component in many cloud native application and service deployments, but also due to the level of access these systems have to all the infrastructure around it.  Most of that access is required for the level of automation organizations are striving to build towards, but forgoing security in this area exposes them in ways they may not know or understand.

schedule.title: Bad Browser: Hunting for Malicious Chrome Extensions
schedule.description: In August 2019 Google announced its *Developer Data Protection Reward Program*, a hackerone bounty program to identify and mitigate data abuse issues in popular Android applications, OAuth projects, and Chrome extensions. Custom tooling was developed to crawl the Chrome extension store and triage extensions that were in scope (over 50,000 installs). A deep dive into the permissions, data tracking and communications was performed. Indicators from previous chrome extension malware campaigns were used to pivot and hunt for malicious extensions. **This talk will expose an ecosystem of malicious Chrome extensions with millions of installs. **Audience members will leave the talk with knowledge on how to quickly triage chrome extension and mostly will be horrified of chrome extensions.

schedule.title: Harry Potter and the InfoSec Apprentice
schedule.description: Harry Potter and his friends taught valuable lessons about love, loyalty, and … security? The InfoSec Apprentice takes scenes out of the Harry Potter books to explain different security concepts. We will talk about password rotation and layered defenses. There is a bit about encryption in The Chamber of Secrets. It is so much easier to understand social engineering and brute-force attacks by highlighting those moments in the books. The stories are also useful for explaining harder topics such as secret sharing and encrypted communications. We use the familiar stories to show how to teach people about security in a way that is fun and relevant.

schedule.title: When a Plan Comes Together: Building a SOC A-Team
schedule.description: Building and running a security operations team is an immense challenge. We need people who are simultaneously analysts, engineers, investigators, rapid responders, customer service specialists, and more - yet, operations work is often treated as a menial task one does before moving on to something more specialized. Little wonder, then, that we have trouble fielding (and maintaining) effective secops capabilities. Working in a SOC should be challenging and engaging, but we need the right team and the right approach to make it so. In this talk, we’ll explore these challenges and discuss creative ways to find, train, and *retain* a security operations “A-Team”.

schedule.title: There's No Place like (DUAL)Homed
schedule.description: In this talk we will venture down the yellow brick road of bypassing dual homed systems.  This will show that using dual homed systems instead of a proper firewall is not ample protection.  I will a be showing how to go deep into the networks in order to compromise them. Will be showing an example of how I was able to go 3 networks deep just by using SMB and Cobalt Strike.

schedule.title: Don’t over roast your ideas, good enough is enough: a look at event security from the perspective of a purple team
schedule.description:
From a small concert at a bar to conventions of over sixty thousand people, events are the passion projects of many. A culmination of hours of planning, stress, and split second solution's. Events have gotten harder to plan as the years progress as you have to look at the risks to your event and attendees as well as your ability to put on the event itself. 
Breaking down events that we have attended, observed and helped evaluate we have found some common ideas that can help event planners and redteamers. The concept that good enough is enough. If you have a solution to a problem you do not have to plan out every single detail and situation as there are too many variables. This talk will break down some of the high level considerations and risks that need to be evaluated when planning an event and how these considerations change based on your event size. Then we will run through a hypothetical threat scenario and break down a series of attack vectors and how they could be exploited. Concluding with solutions that are good enough to help mitigate and prevent the risks events may face.

schedule.title: Harvesting Botnets for Unusual Data
schedule.description: After reviewing over 10 billion botnets records, a lot of unusual records come to mind. Unlike much of stolen data, botnets do a great job in record keeping. Who, when, where, what and even sometimes how and why questions get answered. Let's try connecting credentials stolen by a botnet and an unattributed breach and we may be able to tell who was breached, and even when. When web or network admin gets infected by a virus, what happens to their website/network? What data do botnet administrators sell, what do they discard, what do they keep for themselves? What are the attack and distribution patterns based on botnet's first records? This presentation which is based on research and practical examples will lift a veil off the botnets and will make mining data significantly more actionable.

schedule.title: Avoiding the Apocalypse with Proper Root Cause Analysis
schedule.description:
The end is near. The network lies in ruins. Security tools are now forbidden on the network. Could this disaster have been avoided? If you can’t properly perform root cause analysis (RCA) as a security practitioner, then this event is likely in your future. Through proper application of RCA methods, you can not only avoid networking teams using the nuclear option on you, but actually be the hero by helping solve their problems too! These techniques will also ensure that you are not playing whack-a-mole by only solving surface problems and instead eradicate entire classes of issues.
This presentation will cover the basics of RCA processes including the “5 Whys” and Ishakawa diagrams and using them to solve real-life computing problems, some of which almost caused the cessation of all security activities. Things are going to break and everyone needs to know how to fix them. Attendees can expect to learn how to examine problems that occur thoroughly to ensure they are fixing systemic issues to effect significant improvements in their businesses. This presentation is accessible to attendees of all skill and experience levels. An understanding of basic security technologies and terminologies will be useful for a complete understanding of all the vignettes.

schedule.title: Break crypto like a pro!
schedule.description:
Cryptography is tricky. Sure, everybody knows not to roll out their own crypto, but is it enough? Are the standard algorithms, libraries, and utilities always used the right way? This is of course a rhetorical question! Humans keep making mistakes that other humans can exploit, and Murphy’s law continues to prove true: “If there is a wrong way to do something, then someone will do it.”

In this talk, not only will we discuss what can go wrong, but also how attackers could take advantage of that. Insufficient entropy? Static initialization vector? Key reuse in stream cipher? Lack of ciphertext integrity? We’ve heard these terms and may be familiar with them in theory, but let’s see actual examples of these and other crypto mistakes and corresponding exploits, and understand how they could lead to real life problems.

Are you not on a red team and not interested in exploitation? Then this talk is for you too! Come and learn how to avoid common crypto mistakes in your code!

schedule.title: Stop buying blinkey boxes: Using the tools you have to drastically increase your security posture
schedule.description: Let’s tackle the easiest, cheapest, and most effective ways to secure your environment that you can complete before your next conference. Most talks get into the weeds so much can you get lost. I want to provide you with information that is going to easy to digest and will make your jobs much easier. You’re going to go to more in depth and more technical talks, but I want you to be able to leave here with a punch list you can implement yourself. I’m going to walk you through the punch list and show you how to implement each.

schedule.title: OSINT and the Hermit Kingdom. Leveraging online sources to learn more about the worlds most secret nation
schedule.description: OSINT tools provide security analysts with a powerful set of tools and data that can be leveraged to discover accounts, infrastructure, and long forgotten services that are still running. Using these sources we can research specific companies or users, find easy targets for bug bounties, and begin reconnaissance efforts against our own systems. Learn more about different techniques to gather information while examining North Korea’s public facing infrastructure.

schedule.title: Hey, InfoSec: Try Holding It Like This
schedule.description: Learn to talk to diverse audiences about security and privacy more successfully. Take home real-world-tested analogies, pictures, and stories that you can have, hack, and use to break through to more successful conversations with your family, friends, colleagues, and current and future clients.

schedule.title: DDoS Mitigation Fundamentals
schedule.description:
In this talk the attendees will go over the basics of Denial of Service. It starts with coverage of the different parts of the stack that can be attacked and transitions into a discussion about the currently popular types of DDoS: reflection attacks, SYN flood, Sloworis, etc.

While it covers different attack types, it supplements the attack descriptions with detailed technical explanation of the specific operating system components like sockets, buffers, etc.

Apart from covering specific technique the talk will cover general strategies using external resources such as CDNs and dedicated DDoS mitigation providers, anycast, etc.

The talk is specifically tailored to incident responders who normally do not operate the network but need to be on par with the network operators during an attack, and prepares them to ask the right questions in the planning phases, to help drive towards a resilient architecture.

The talk focuses on the technologies and not on particular vendor implementation.

schedule.title: Intel for Threat Intel, an Open Source Journey of a Budgeted Threat Intelligence Program
schedule.description: With Threat Intelligence being a hot topic these days, many companies are faced with a decision to invest in a Threat Intelligence Program. However, gaining good intel doesn’t depend on how much you invest in some expensive product. In fact, we are going to share with you how we formed a Threat Intelligence Program from the ground up. We will show you how you too can form a solid Threat Intel Program in as little as a few months while automating many of the processes. Join us as we discuss our journey and the tools that helped get us there such as MISP (Threat Intelligence Platform), Atomic Red Team (MITRE ATTACK Simulation), and Cuckoo (Malware Analysis Sandbox). Our goal is to provide a Threat Intelligence solution that scales for ANY size team without breaking the bank.**strong text**

schedule.title: Airplane Mode: Cybersecurity @ 30,000+ Feet
schedule.description: Imagine being in charge of a system where you own the product. You do not own the software and the hardware is proprietary. You need to coordinate with multiple vendors for any updates or modifications and you’re under strict government regulation. By the way, the product has a lifespan of 20 - 30 years. Welcome to the world of aviation cybersecurity, where safety and security live together. At a high level, this presentation will cover what is aviation cyber security, the unique challenges it represents and why the industry is captivating.

schedule.title: Doing ‘Simple’ at scale: Implementing the first six of the CIS top 20 with open source, free tools, and home-grown tools
schedule.description: One of the hardest tasks I do in my role as an IT Security Practitioner for a global financial services company is ‘doing the simple’ at scale. Today, IT Security has become a critical cornerstone for the executive board. Security teams now have the resources, budget, and support that we have traditionally not had access to. This is when we can we become obsessed with the ‘latest and greatest’, the ‘next-next gen’, the ‘flashy dashboard’ and we fall into the trap of ignoring ‘the basics’. The pyramids from ancient Egypt stand tall today in large part to being built on a solid foundation. How can we, as an IT Security team protect assets that we know nothing about? If we are not vigilant and put controls in place to secure a solid foundation the waves of time will erode our environment. Join us as we dive deep on how we can address some of the basic foundational controls using open source, free tools, and home-grown tools on a global level.

schedule.title: Everyone Can Play! Building CTFs To Teach Non-Security Folks
schedule.description:
Most security practitioners are aware of the learning and fun that comes from participating in Capture the Flag competitions. Racing against other teams, solving brain-twisting challenges and seeing new ways to compromise systems teaches and entertains.
CTFs are also a great tool to give non-security folks a hands on understanding of how security vulnerabilities enable criminal activities, reduce user privacy and degrade system reliability. 
In this session you will learn to build interesting, educational and easy to use Capture the Flag events targeted at developers and other technical, non-security, users.
We will cover specific considerations for each audience you target, how to create interesting (yet solvable) challenges, and how to make the overall experience friction free for the participants.
You will also learn tools and techniques to create easily repeatable, consistent events with minimal work. We will cover collaborative development, external system integration techniques, tooling and a fully automated deployment pipeline to make spinning up a new CTF as easy as pushing a button.

schedule.title: Lend me your IR’s!
schedule.description: Have you ever felt compelled to tip your cap to a malicious threat actor? Protecting systems and networks as a tech defender means withstanding a constant barrage of unsophisticated attacks from automated tools, botnets, crawlers, exploit kits, phish kits, and script kiddies; oh my! Once in a while we encounter attacks worthy of style points for creativity or new twists on old attack techniques. This talk features live demo reenactments from some advanced attacks investigated by the presenter. The live demos showcase technical deep dives of the underpinnings from both the attacker and investigator sides of these attacks. Attendee key takeaways are strategies, freely available tools, and techniques helpful during incident response investigations.

schedule.title: Marketing and Branding for Security: Building a Security First Culture
schedule.description: Security teams often feel they are fighting a losing battle against their users. Developers don’t listen and business leaders just accept risk. It’s not that users don’t care; it’s that they lack context to understand why they should care. This session explores how one corporation was able to take a small presentation about cybersecurity risks and turn it into a security champions program by engaging and empowering developers and business leaders to understand why security is so important. Attendees will leave with actionable tips for implementing similar programs in their own organizations.

schedule.title: CLOUDy with a chance of Breach!
schedule.description: While the cloud is a powerful ally, it is not a silver bullet. Cloud-sprawl, sub-optimal configurations, credential misuse, and other issues are heightened as part of a cloud security architecture. Join us as we present on how to apply the CIS 20 Security Controls to cloud environments. This session will be vendor agnostic and will provide attendees with real world tips and tricks they can immediately implement. At the end of this talk we hope ‘that the clouds floating into your environment, carry no rain, nor FUD, but add to the value of your environment’.

schedule.title: Meet CAFIR: Automated Incident Response & Forensics in the Cloud
schedule.description:
The words “there is a cloud incident” is a phrase that is all too often uttered as organizations rapidly deploy a plethora of tools, technologies, and capabilities to the cloud. As an IT professional, the ability to quickly and efficiently identify, contain, remediate, and investigate cloud incidents when they arise, may seem like an exceedingly daunting task without the proper knowledge and tools. This talk will focus on GCP (Google Cloud Platform) and the methods that can be leveraged to effectively conduct digital forensics and incident response (DFIR) tasks. While GCP offers a user friendly API and SDK, there are multiple steps involved in containing a host, collecting a disk image, and conducting other needed DFIR tasks. 

In addition to exploring the GCP-native commands that can be leveraged for forensics and incident response, a new cloud automation tool will be released that can be leveraged to speed up identification, containment, response, and analysis in GCP. This innovative DFIR assistant is CAFIR (Cloud Automated Forensics & Incident Response). CAFIR is a one stop shop to streamline, simplify, and speed up incident response and forensics tasks in GCP as well as providing the ability for IT security professionals to conduct investigations in GCP without the need to research and understand GCP specific tools and commands.

schedule.title: Building a better pentester
schedule.description:
Abstract: We're professional breakers. We get to hack into systems for a living, and 
we appear as ninja-magician-tech-pirates to the untrained eye. We find vulnerabilities.
We help businesses protect themselves. 

That being said, it's easy to get caught up in dropping shells and flexing on developers, and sometimes we miss that we're failing to make a bigger difference. During this presentation, we'll talk about improving technical and non-technical skills, we'll share war-stories and memes, and listeners will leave with actionable ways to become the best pentesters around.

schedule.title: PowerShell to the People!
schedule.description:
## Overview

The goal of this presentation is to share knowledge about PowerShell that would be valuable for anyone that wants to learn more, no matter what level of PowerShell foo you are at.  The ultimate hope is that everyone walks away with use cases and tools they could use today.   

## Outline

1. get-help - we all need it..
2. PS has a .profile?!  And how I use it.
3. Never use ADUC again - Powershell AD Tools and the cool things therein
4. send-malwareMail.ps1 <– IR Automation Use Case
5. You like your C# code that much, lets add-type   <-- Time permitting

[Repository Location](https://github.com/lawlz/PSToThePeople)

schedule.title: Working Remote Is Isolating, Notifications are Overwhelming, What Is Going On?
schedule.description: Many people struggle silently with feelings of being overwhelmed, isolated or guilt ridden when it comes to working remote and falling behind. In Information Security we are notorious for pressuring ourselves to not miss out on the newest things.  FOMO is the Fear of Missing Out and it is making us oversubscribe to groups, social media, other communication channels, and work.  Friends, family and strangers tell us how lucky we are to work remotely, but why do we not feel the same? This talk will discuss the many different ways fear may be present in your life and what are some steps to help you set up your remote office and avoid feeling overwhelmed, isolated and not motivated.

schedule.title: Lies, Deception and Manipulation: Let's talk about Deepfakes
schedule.description:
Digital image and video manipulation has reached a new level of sophistication. From the simple "Photoshop" to the modern equivalent in video, fakes are becoming more and more difficult to spot. This makes them a great candidate for abuse.

For years we have been telling people that what they post on the internet will be there to stay and can have huge ramifications later in life, but what if they don't actually do what is portrayed?

Modern technology can use Machine Learning and AI to dissect videos, extract faces and build virtual models that are used to automatically replace the faces, all while retaining eye blinks and facial expressions. 

For millions of people, realistic fakes can ruin a career, destroy families and possibly even influence elections. Even if proven fake later, the damage can be irreversible and in this digital age, can last a lifetime. 

This session will look at the technology behind creating these fakes, potential attacks using the technology and what is being done to combat this trend and protect us from what even appears to be ourselves.

schedule.title: Fear, Uncertainty, and DICOM.  How to mitigate all three.
schedule.description:
The current DICOM vulnerabilities have raised a lot of questions about how to
secure radiology systems and ensure that images are accurate. This session
will discuss potential solutions to address them.  It will also address the FUD that medical device security vendors have been using to push snake oil that doesn't solve the problem and actually causes more.  Attendees will learn how to cut past the FUD and put diagnostic imaging systems in place that work and are actually secured.

schedule.title: Creating APT targeted threat feeds for your industry
schedule.description: A presentation on how the open-source threat intelligence platform MISP and MITRE ATT&CK can be used to target the Advanced Persistent Threat groups that target your industry to produce weighted feeds that can be fed to your security tools (SIEM, IDS, etc.). The idea is that your log sources can be optimized for proper visibility and IOCs can be better recognized earlier in the kill chain before persistence is gained.

schedule.title: ./senua -v :: The Swiftly Sneaky C2
schedule.description: Command and control can be performed in many ways: over the HTTP protocol, through DNS, through ICMP.  How about less common methods like social media? My presentation expands upon command and control through Reddit and takes it to a whole other level.  With this presentation, I will primarily focus on the usage of Swift and Apple’s built in API calls to the system.  I aim to teach how most EDR solutions don’t observe system API calls allowing any form of command to be performed without any detection.  From there, I will also focus on using AWS infrastructure for the backend of the system responses and Reddit for the initial commands being sent to the system.  During this demonstration, I will present the application’s custom built shell (named ASH for API Shell) and thoroughly explain the code so that others can replicate it.

schedule.title: Git it Together - Finding and Preventing Leaky Git Secrets
schedule.description:
Uh-oh, you just uploaded your AWS credentials! How did *that* happen? How can it be prevented? How can an attacker exploit that mistake?
 
Together we'll find the answer to that question and more, as we explore what leads to people publishing their secrets to GitHub, different ways it can be prevented, and how these critical errors can be detected after they occur.
 
Finally, we’ll explore how to use these techniques to find other people’s secrets, and look at some of the gems encountered on the trek through the GitHub credential wasteland.

schedule.title: Automating Vulnerability Management from Scratch
schedule.description:
Did you know that an average of 14,600 vulnerabilities are disclosed each year? How are you handling your discovered vulnerabilities? Vulnerability management is a difficult task, especially at a large organization. In fact, it takes an average of 100 days until known security vulnerabilities are remediated. Often times vulnerability management is implemented in segments, without a big picture vision. It can be also arduous and cumbersome, costing employees valuable time and effort. However, vulnerability management is a necessity in today's cyber security landscape.

In this talk, we discuss where vulnerability management programs fall short and how we can avoid such pitfalls. We will walk through a typical program and the pain points. Once we understand the problem, we will enhance the process through automating asset inventory and daily vulnerability collection. We will also demonstrate how using automation to search asset inventory for newly discovered vulnerabilities increases speed and efficiency of the team and helps to more quickly create action items from discovered vulnerabilities. In addition, our process will help teams determine which vulnerabilities are the riskiest and organize them by remediation priority.

The vulnerability management program is built from the ground up across a complex work environment using Python3, Jenkins, SQL, and a few extra tips and tricks. Proof-of-concept code will be open sourced at the conclusion of the discussion and attendees will leave this talk with the ability to implement similar automated vulnerability management solutions in their environments.

schedule.title: Nightmares of Information & Cyber Security Officers in a Research Organization
schedule.description: What keeps a CISO up at night? The core purpose of information security is protecting against the unauthorized use of information utilizing Confidentiality, Security & Availability. But what if the information you are protecting is part of a larger scientific collaboration that is a menagerie of individuals who are notorious for both hoarding & sharing data? The following talk will dive into the psychology of a ‘scientific researcher’ with real world examples of interesting challenges posed to Information Security managers and lessons learned from the trenches. Participants will take away some new strategies on how using the principles of Confidentiality, Integrity & Availability to engage with scientific researchers (referred to as highly intelligent cats) to better adopt existing Information Security programs in your company.

schedule.title: What the CISO is really looking for
schedule.description: Mitch Parker has been a healthcare CISO since 2008.  During this time, he has been a first hand witness to the evolution of this role from a primarily technical role to its current hybrid business/policy/technical mix.  This means that people in this role have to effectively straddle the roles of technical security understanding, business, contract management, legal and regulatory knowledge, policy, privacy, and project management to be able to help their customers navigate the very difficult landscape.  This has helped him assist multiple customers in maturing programs from inception to maturity.  This session will help technical staff and aspiring management learn what they need to know to effectively apply it in their business for their customers.

schedule.title: 0Day to HeroDay: Bringing a company from scorched earth to a modern security organization
schedule.description: This talk will outline how a company was brought down to its knees from a ransomware attack, how it rose from the ashes, and how it now has a full security organization.  Ryan will take you through the thrilling adventure of building incident response, system architecture, disaster recovery, and system operations on the fly while the business was down - and how the group ensured the business could come back online without risk of reinfection. Then, he will discuss how he started a security organization from scratch and talk through the challenges of maturing an organization that was on the brink of destruction just a few months ago.

schedule.title: CyberSafari: Underexamined threat actors from the global threat landscape
schedule.description: Typical discussions around state-nexus threat actors focus on Pandas (China), Bears (Russia), Kittens (Iran), and Chollimas (North Korea). While those actors tend to be the most high-profile, the threat landscape includes enough activity from Cranes (South Korea), Leopards (Pakistan), Buffalos (Vietnam) and more to constitute a whole cyber-safari of underexamined actors. This sub-set of adversaries represents the proliferation of how more and more state-nexus actors are increasingly conducting targeted intrusions, intent on capitalizing on the asymmetric advantages offered by cyber operations. By examining these actors and their activity, we can see the diversity of their motivations, methodologies, and targets. This allows for a more accurate understanding how truly global the threat landscape is and subsequently better tailor threat models and defensive postures.

schedule.title: No One Cares How L33t You Are: Providing Actual Value in Penetration Tests
schedule.description:
Too many penetration tests become silly demonstrations of how awesome the tester is, with little value actually provided to the organization. If you're constructing attacks purely to get amazing screenshots showing how awesome you are, you're probably doing it wrong. Your client doesn't care. They're paying you to help them improve things, not just to show how cool you are. 

In this talk, we'll explore best practices for scoping and executing tests to provide actual benefit to customers. We'll talk about the intent of penetration testing and use real work examples to explore what really matters to clients.  Attendees will walk away with specific ideas they can take home to improve their assessments.

schedule.title: Practical security in the brave new Kubernetes world
schedule.description: Kubernetes' broad adoption has triggered a growth of frameworks, tools and technologies supporting it. It also means a growth in the attack surface. Instead of taking Kubernetes clusters head on, learn how to do a recon on a real-world k8s cluster and the common sets of sidecar containers that it relies on. Then see what it takes to pwn ingress point, service mesh, network infrastructure, package manager and performance monitoring tools. From there, get persistence in Docker registries and images.

schedule.title: CTF Wrapup Starring Lintile!
schedule.description: Curious how the CTF was made?  Tune into CTF Wrapup with Lintile to explain just how he brought this year's game to life!

schedule.title: Demystifying RFCs: Practical Applications for Security and the Apocalypse
schedule.description: Request for Comments (RFCs) lay the foundation for the Internet and all of its interworking. However, many folks in the Information Security community have very little familiarity with them. This presentation will dissect the format of the RFC, explain how they are created and categorized, and provide several security-related use cases, all with the intention of bringing relevance to these often-difficult-to-read documents. There will also be a moment of levity included, by showing how knowledge of RFCs could possibly help rebuild civilization after the Apocalypse.

schedule.title: Between a SOC and a Hard Place
schedule.description: The Security Operations Center, everyone has one, but is it really more than a checkbox or a place to go where dreams die? This talk will discuss some of the core issues that SOC’s face today as well as suggestions and ideas to get this pivotal role and department back on mission by trusting and empowering analysts to find badness.

schedule.title: A Pitmaster's Guide To Security Design
schedule.description: What do great BBQ and good security design principles have in common? It turns out, quite a bit. Good BBQ requires a mix of certain unquestionable techniques and an artistic approach that each practitioner must bring to their unique situation and goals. This is also the case when it comes to designing and deploying security controls. However, just as some cooks ignore those proven techniques and end up ruining a good cut of meat, IT and security professionals also sometimes fail to follow foundational best practices when architecting security solutions. This results in vulnerabilities and eventually breaches of those environments. This session will take lessons from good BBQ techniques and apply them to our security architecture. We'll examine five rules all good pitmasters swear by and see how those same concepts can form a framework of security defense design that eliminates common pitfalls. By the end of this talk, you'll not only have gained practical knowledge for improving the defensive posture of your IT systems, you'll also be better equipped to smoke a killer brisket!

schedule.title: Data Science Plus Security
schedule.description:
This is an interactive course, with the goal of teaching security professionals how to implement data science techniques in order to obtain valuable insights. This course will encompass various topics including: feature engineering, exploratory data analysis, data visualization, machine learning and probabilistic graphical models. I believe the combination of data science and security allows the security community to move our assumptions, opinions and beliefs into knowledge. This two day course teaches attendees the data science concepts, techniques and processes for analyzing various security datasets.

No previous data science experience is necessary as this course is designed for those who are new to data science. Background understanding programming is very helpful, specifically Python.

schedule.title: AWS Study Cram
schedule.description: Getting started in tech can be a difficult process. We often feel we don't know enough to even know what we need to learn. Friends will recommend that we begin by seeking certifications to help us stand out in the job market, which is great, but what certification do you start with? The AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner examination is intended for individuals who are seeking the knowledge and skills necessary to effectively demonstrate an overall understanding of the AWS Cloud. During our study cram you will learn about the fundamentals of the AWS Cloud, along with building an outline of what you will need to study in order to build your cloud skills, and grow your professional credibility. This study cram is great for anyone looking to work with the AWS cloud. If you are looking for a place to start your journey or perhaps came to this conference with a friend or family member and would love to learn what in the world they are talking about, we have a place for you here.

schedule.title: Threat Hunting with the Elastic Stack
schedule.description:
In this hands-on training event, students learn how to perform **network security analytics** with the Elastic Stack and **cyber hunt operations** using RockNSM. The event starts with a brief overview of how to visualize network data and hunt for malicious activities and aggressors that evade detection from traditional signature-based tools such as anti-virus and intrusion detection systems.

From there, the training moves on to cyberspace hunt scenarios that are both individual and team based. The hunt exercises apply a learning model that we call **Guided Hunt**, a methodology that challenges students through the use of staged cyber artifacts or breadcrumbs, ensuring that no one is left behind. This **Capture The Flag** environment allows for maximum participation, challenge, and achievement from all participants.

**A personal laptop (any operating system) is required for interacting with the environment!**

schedule.title: Zero Trust: Architecting and Planning
schedule.description:
Zero Trust is quickly developing into a security principle. But hype and buzzwords cast a fog over what it is and how to apply it. Security professionals need to understand which technologies fit the Zero Trust model and how best to configure them. This training session provides a technical overview and a pragmatic approach. The agenda:

•	Introducing the basic components of Zero Trust
•	Aligning the technologies behind Zero Trust
•	Securing people, applications, and devices 
•	Evaluating Zero Trust from an adversarial point of view
•	Planning for Zero Trust architecture

schedule.title: RF Signal Capturing
schedule.description:
I like wires, they're amazing. They string together things. They make your internet do things. But what if they never existed? What if there were no wires anywhere; ever? How would we transmits data?

That's right, Radio waves. Data over the air, traveling at C. Yes, C. C is FAST! And with it we can send information super-duper fast.

In this "course" we'll "learn" about how wireless data signals can be reverse engineered.

I've never taught this course before so a lot is to be developed. Also I need an audience.

schedule.title: Bug Hunting and Web Hacking
schedule.description: Mastering web hacking and bug hunting starts with deep and practical understanding of web servers, technologies and protocols. In this 3 days course, students will be presented to a real bug bounty program hosted in a controlled environment, and the challenge is: How to discover, exploit and report your findings and gain money!?

schedule.title: How to Rock Your CircleCityCon Presentation!
schedule.description: Have a cool security topic the world should know about? Have you wanted to present at CircleCityCon but didn’t know where to start? The goal of this workshop is to arrive with an idea and leave with all you need for an amazing presentation that will keep your audience engaged. Topics covered include how a call for papers works, what to do when you’re accepted, speech delivery basics and day of presentation tips and tricks. Participants will receive digital handouts that walks you through the presentation process tailored to security and tech specific presentations. Laptop optional, but take that next step and have a completed presentation when you leave!

schedule.title: Finding Evil – Introduction to Threat Hunting in ICS Environments
schedule.description:
The practice of Threat Intelligence and the execution of Hunting activities can be difficult to put into practice.  A large amount of information has been published, but in many cases the documentation is high level and not easily applied tactically in day-to-day activities.
 
During this training we will look at common sources of Threat Intelligence and determine what can be useful for sharing internally at your organization.  Taking the information further, we will see how to make use of Threat Intelligence to aid in risk identification and Hunting.
 
Hands-on lab work and discussion will allow attendees to practice related skills.

schedule.title: Everyone Can Play! Building CTFs To Teach Non-Security Folks
schedule.description:
Most security practitioners are aware of the learning and fun that comes from participating in Capture the Flag competitions. Racing against other teams, solving brain-twisting challenges and seeing new ways to compromise systems teaches and entertains.
CTFs are also a great tool to give non-security folks a hands on understanding of how security vulnerabilities enable criminal activities, reduce user privacy and degrade system reliability. 
In this session you will learn to build interesting, educational and easy to use Capture the Flag events targeted at developers and other technical, non-security, users.
We will cover specific considerations for each audience you target, how to create interesting (yet solvable) challenges, and how to make the overall experience friction free for the participants.
You will also learn tools and techniques to create easily repeatable, consistent events with minimal work. We will cover collaborative development, external system integration techniques, tooling and a fully automated deployment pipeline to make spinning up a new CTF as easy as pushing a button.
